lines: Ah… your footsteps are unknown to this soil. Welcome, outsider.
I am Clay, caretaker of all life here in Pebblewick. Long have I tended to these lands, before even the gardens withered.
May you find something here worth nurturing.
You’ve come. Good. Silence can be its own conversation, but to hear a voice again is always appreciated.
There was a time when gardens bloomed in every corner of Pebblewick. The townsfolk would gather, sharing seeds and stories.
The gardens are gone now—replaced by roofs, fences, homes. But one garden remains. Overgrown, derelict. The earth beneath it still hums with memory.
I wish to nurture it back to health, but do not know how. The garden pulses with magic and alchemy—things unknown to me.
Please, if you can, learn more of this garden. Help me to understand what pains it.
Soil is not just dirt. It is memory. Every fallen leaf, every footstep pressed into mud—it all becomes part of the story.
When I press my hand to the ground, I can feel those stories ripple through me.
Most are oblivious to it… but I hear lullabies in loam. Warnings in wilted petals. Joy in the rise of green things.
The world speaks—all one must do is listen.
I have wandered these hills longer than Pebblewick has had a name.
Before stone turned to chimney and the ground was paved, I tended roots and made quiet friends of rabbits.
The people came later, but I stayed. I watched the town grow, settle, change.
Sometimes I miss the wild it once was… but I do not resent the change. All things shift, and still, the earth holds steady beneath it all.
Something feels… lighter. Whatever you did, you have soothed the earth here.
Now, the garden can flourish once again. Thank you, friend.
I only hope that I can do the same…
The garden ached, and you listened.
But… there are aches within me, too. I fear they won’t be so simple to quell.
You have eased a tremor in this old heart.
I may yet thrive alongside the garden. Come. Let us return to it.
I see you’ve met Walnut. Filbert’s been spinning his stories again, hasn’t he?
There is no evil here. Just a squirrel, and a lonely frog who sees more than he says.
Walnut’s been my friend for years. He speaks to me. Filbert has tried to warn me about him seven times. Once with a pie chart.
But I think… maybe Filbert isn’t afraid of Walnut. Maybe he’s afraid Walnut doesn’t like him.
Go on, then. Bring him to Filbert. He’s told me that it’s okay. He suspects that Filbert needs a friend.
Greetings, friend. The soil sings in your presence.
